posts.name: Evan Pendleton
posts.cooked:
The first time we run a PathPlanner auto after a new code deploy or restarting the robot there is always a lag of around 0.5 seconds. This causes a huge decrease in path accuracy; however, as soon as we run it again it works perfectly fine. This leads to inconsistent path following and it not traveling to the desired distance (way undershooting).

Our robot code is here: https://github.com/Spectrum3847/2024-Ultraviolet .

Here is a picture of the telemetry output on PathPlanner: PathPlannerError 2256×1442 251 KB The middle portion of the data is when robot code was running for the first time, and the others were before or after the new code deploy.

PathPlannerError 2256×1442 251 KB

PathPlannerError 2256×1442 251 KB

link_counts.title: Noticeable Delay Between Start of Autonomous and Robot Motion
Every Auto Path Waits Half a Second?

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
Does this happen with all autos or just this one?

Does this happen in simulation too?  When I run your simulation it is completely broken.

What are the other velocities we see in your chart?

Does this happen when dropping into teleop the first time too or just auto?

Do you get any errors/warnings at this time?  Posting logs might give us something to look at.

posts.name: Evan Pendleton
posts.cooked:
jdaming:

Does this happen with all autos or just this one?

It happens in all autos.

jdaming:

Does this happen in simulation too? When I run your simulation it is completely broken.

We haven’t configured it to run in simulation yet, so we can’t test it there.

jdaming:

What are the other velocities we see in your chart?

4 m/s^2 acceleration and 3 m/s velocity.

jdaming:

Does this happen when dropping into teleop the first time too or just auto?

We tried mapping the PathPlanner command to a button in teleop and it resulted in the same error (this happened regardless of when we hit the button in teleop, so it still occurred after moving the drivetrain).

jdaming:

Do you get any errors/warnings at this time? Posting logs might give us something to look at.

Here is a photo of our logs: LoopOverrun 1323×742 94.9 KB It looks like it might be a loop overrun issue with the first time autos are run (1 Meter Auto.execute takes 0.038 seconds to run, causing the loop overrun).

LoopOverrun 1323×742 94.9 KB

LoopOverrun 1323×742 94.9 KB

Thank you for your help.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
I don’t see anything obvious here are a few things to try (not solutions just trying to narrow down the problem):

Try commenting out the named commands and rotation target override.

Try using buildAutoChooser

What is the state of testing for your drivetrain code?  Seems very similar to CTRE swerve is there a reason to not use that?

Try without advantagekit

There is a lot going on in the project (even though what is running should be simple)

posts.name: Evan Pendleton
posts.cooked:
We tried all of these options, but everything produced similar lag.

We were able to take data from our initial code and it produced similar lag every time. Here is a screenshot of our spreadsheet below (PathPlannerAutoName.execute always took the most amount of time by a significant magnitude). Error Data 1013×316 27.3 KB

Error Data 1013×316 27.3 KB

Error Data 1013×316 27.3 KB

Here is a slow-mo video of our robot running the auto the first time after a code deploy:

Photo Gallery for Spectrum 3847 the FIRST Robotics Competition FRC Team from St. Agnes Academy and Strake Jesuit College Prep High Schools in Houston, Texas

Here is a slow-mo video of our robot running the auto a second time after a code deploy:

Photo Gallery for Spectrum 3847 the FIRST Robotics Competition FRC Team from St. Agnes Academy and Strake Jesuit College Prep High Schools in Houston, Texas

It looks like the robot starts to move in auto as soon as the Loop Overrun message appears (around 14.8 seconds or so). In the second video it appears to happen immediately.

EDIT: Also, adding a 0.2 second wait command in the PathPlanner auto didn’t fix anything.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Java loads classes “on demand” (the first time a function is called in a class, the class is loaded).  This means the first call may take significantly longer than later calls, particularly for cases when there’s a lot of static construction or the function pulls in many other classes, such as loading json does.  There’s really not a good workaround for this other than trying to find ways to exercise the code path in disabled; I was doing some work in the offseason on a (conservative) class preloader but the Rio really doesn’t have enough memory for that.
